explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_solids.rationale: Non-combustible inorganic compound (it is reported to be not combustible (ICSC)).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: There is a product made of this substance dissolved in water.

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Since its rat LD50 = 40 mg/kg by oral administration (EU-RAR (2005)), the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Since its rabbit LD50 = 1330 mg/kg (EU-RAR (2002)), the substance was classified into Category 4.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Since the substance is a solid (GHS definition), it was classified into the "Not applicable" category.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Since its rat LC50 = 0.104 mg/L (4 hours) (EU-RAR (2005)), the substance was classified into Category 2.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description that water-soluble Cr (VI) compounds are corrosive (EU-RAR (2005)), the substance was classified into Category 1.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description that water-soluble Cr (VI) compounds cause irreversible and severe damage to the eyes (EU-RAR (2005)), the substance was classified into Category 1. It has been classified into Category 1 for skin corrosion as well.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Cr (VI) compounds containing sodium salts are reported to cause respiratory tract sensitization in humans (EU-RAR (2005)). Thus, the substance was classified into Category 1.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Cr (VI) compounds containing sodium salts are reported to cause skin sensitization in guinea pigs (EU-RAR (2005)). Thus, the substance was classified into Category 1.

carcinogenicity.rationale: In vivo alkaline elution assay gave positive results (IUCLID (2000)) and in inhalation exposure test using rats, DNA damage was found in the lung (RTECS accessed in October 2007). Since various in vitro tests gave positive results (IARC 49 (1990)) and water-soluble Cr (VI) compounds were suggested to be mutagenic in in-vivo system (EU-RAR (2005), IARC 49 (1990)), we classified the substance into Category 2.

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Cr (VI) compounds are rated as "Group 1" by the IARC (IARC vol. 49 (1996)), "Group 2" by the EU (EU 2007), and "Group 1" by Japan Society for Occupational Health (Recommendations of Occupational Exposure Limits 2007). Based on these ratings, the substance was classified into Category 1A.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Since there are no test results available on this substance, classification is not possible. As related information, in developmental toxicity test in which potassium dichromate, a kind of Cr (VI) compounds, was applied to mice, increased premature births and dead fetuses and decreased number of fetuses per litter were noted (EU-RAR (2005)).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (respiratory system, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: There is a report that inhalation by humans of aqueous solutions of Cr (VI) mists have resulted in necrosis of the bronchi and edemas of the lungs. In addition, swallowing of the substance by humans resulted in liver and kidney damage (EU-RAR (2005)). Based on these results, the substance was classified into Category 1 (respiratory system, kidney, and liver).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system, kidney)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Repeated exposure to Cr (VI) including sodium chromate in humans resulted in respiratory system and kidney damage (EU-RAR (2005)). Based on this report, the substance was classified into Category 1 (respiratory system and kidney).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since 48-hour EC50 = 0.05 mg/L for crustaceans (Daphnia magna) (EU, 2005), the substance was classified into Category 1.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Its classification for acute toxicity is Category 1; it is a metal compound and its movement in the water and its potential for bioaccumulation is unclear. Based on this information, the substance was classified into Category 1.
